learningObject.bleedingImage:
It's easy to forget that something fun can have some risks and cyber criminals are well aware when we are at our most vulnerable.

Perhaps there's a patch or cheat that you can use? Or a offer of cheap skins or other game gear. These are all great routes to get you to install malware on your computer. 

Multi-player games are just as much a part of social media as Instagram but there are usually no barrier to chatting with people you've never met in real life. You can't be sure who you're talking with so never use your real name or reveal personal information.

Do you consider the risks when posting photos? 

This is what online predators look for in photos others post:

  • Is there enough room to 'superimpose' another figure into the image?
  • Are they in a state of undress (even with emoticons placed modestly - these can be removed and body parts can be digitally copied in).

Do you know who you're talking to?

It is really easy to pretend to be someone other than you are on social media - that is one of the reasons it is popular. Don't agree to meet in real life without an adult to accompany you.

Do you know why they are talking to you?

Are they recruiting a friend or a victim? Be very careful of individuals expressing extreme views on any topic. Talk it out with someone you trust.

It’s not your fault - it's the bully that's got the problem

  • Keep the offending post/message (take a screenshot - but not in Snapchat*)
  • Don’t reply to the sender
  • Block the offender and un-friend them
  • Involve an adult - a parent, sibling, or someone you trust
  • Report problems promptly to the social network or mobile phone operator
  • For serious issues, you should involve the police - this includes inappropriate sexual suggestions, racist remarks, ongoing bullying or harassment

Trolls are not as anonymous as they think they are - it is always worth reporting a problem.

 

* Snapchat will report to the troll that a screenshot has been taken. Take a picture of your screen with another camera.

Online shopping is really convenient for cyber criminals - you can just give them your payment card details!

The green padlock symbol (and often the word secure)  at the start of the web site's address will tell you that the connection between you and the site and is private so that a 'man in the middle' cannot see the details you type. 

This doesn't guarantee the site is safe though. Criminals can clone web sites that look exactly like real online stores so always be careful of links in emails directing you to today's special offer. But whenever you are asked for payment details it should always be there. 

Never reveal personal information like PIN numbers or login details when ordering things - this could be a very bad sign!

What do you think personal information is?

  • Your phone number
  • Where your parents work
  • Where you go 
  • Where you live
  • Your date of birth
  • Your national insurance number
  • Your bank details
  • Passwords
  • Where you used to live
  • Who your friends are
  • Your pet's name

The list is almost endless and most of these are pieces of information you obviously wouldn't share publicly. But all these little pieces of information can be drawn from your 'digital footprint' and used to: impersonate you; steal from you; manipulate you; hurt you!

Be very careful who you reveal personal information and always ask why? when organisations ask for information that doesn't seem relevant, even if they appear to be legitimate.

Social media apps are a great way to stay in touch and share information, but you can share too much!

You need to be very aware of:

Loss of control: Once you post it, it can’t be taken back even if you regret it. You should think before you send anything, only post content you’d be proud to put your name against!

Trusting Peers: Beware of peer pressure and following the crowd, don’t be pressured into oversharing just because there’s an expectation of trust. Take care of yourself first and follow your gut when it comes to sharing personal details and content.

Location information: Pictures and videos can share information about where you go, what you own and what you do. This can be very useful for a criminal.

It's essential that you check your privacy settings, as well as the terms and conditions for using an application - you may be giving your videos and pictures to someone to use however they wish.

Smart phones and tablets use is growing at 10 times that of PCs. We are using those devices in more locations to do more things. By the end of 2014 there were as many mobile devices as people on the planet.

As a result, they are more and more attactive to cyber criminals. So it is important to:

  • always set a passcode (or fingerprint/face recognition)
  • logout of your accounts when they are not being used
  • only download and install from trusted sources

The Internet of Things is eclipsing that of mobile and the number of connected devices is growing at an exponential rate. It is estimated that by 2020, there will be 26 billion connected devices*. The types of connected devices in the home range from smart TVs, home security systems and refrigerators to coffee machines. This volume of connected devices means that threats are also increasing. 

If you have internet connected devices in your home, make sure that:

  • you register the device with the manufacturer and apply updates when prompted
  • change any default administration password to a strong one of your own
  • disconnect devices that are not in use
  • cover web camera lenses when they are not in use
  • avoid buying cheap devices without any form of security

 

* Source: Gartner.com
learningObject.textGraphics:
Love them or hate them, passwords are part of our daily life. But what makes a GOOD password?

Simply speaking, it needs to be:

  • Hard for a hacker to guess
  • Slow for a computer to attack by brute force
  • Easy to remember
  • Easy to associate with the site you are trying to access

The strongest passwords use a mixture of letters, numbers and other characters.

Longer passwords - 12 characterts or more is better - can be remembered by using a phrase, song lyrics or a mental image.

To help you remember passwords for specific sites, add a letter or word that links your password to the site. The main part of your password can still be the same for several sites.

• Install the security updates on your PC, Mac, Phone, router, smart TV, Webcam …. or at least make sure that automatic updates are not turned off.
  • Using old hardware or operating systems (Windows XP) is risky
  • Microsoft won't end security updates for your Windows 7 PC until Jan. 14, 2020

tabNav.name: Malware
tabNav.text:
'Malware' is short for malicious software and can appear in a number of different forms such as viruses, spyware,  worms, trojans, rootkits and ransomware.

They are all designed to steal something from you and are a source of a great deal of cyber crime. Sometimes what they steal isn't obvious - there has been a big rise in malware that uses your computer to 'mine' for cryptocurrencies such as bitcoin. Your bandwidth, computer power and electricity are valuable!

nestedPage.name: How does malware get on my computer?
nestedPage.text:
The most common ways are:

  • Visiting a malicious web site which can silently install the malware,
  • Following a link in an email which could run a script or direct you to a malicious web site,
  • Clicking a pop-up on a web site,
  • Attaching an infected or malicious USB device,
  • Being connected to a network where there is an infected computer,
  • Giving access to someone to your computer physically or through remote access.

nestedPage.name: How can I stop it?
nestedPage.text:
Avoiding the main ways that malware is installed is the obvious solution, but this isn't always easy.

Installing (and keeping up to date) anti-virus and anti-malware applications can help, as can applications that warn you about suspicious web sites.

Be sure of the identity of anyone you give access to your computer, especially if they contacted you in the first place.

Probably the most effective solution is to never follow links from an email or at least hovering over the link to check that the web address appears to be valid.

But it is very likely that you will be affected at some point so keep your valuable files backed up and away from your computer. There are many cloud services to choose from that can keep your computer files synchonised with the cloud.

nestedPage.name: What can I do if my computer is affected?
nestedPage.text:
Disconnect from the Internet or your network as soon as possible to avoid spreading the problem and denying access to your computer by an attacker.

Restore your operating system to an earlier date - if that fails, re-install your operating system.

You do store your important files away from your computer, don't you?

nestedPage.name: Free can be dangerous
nestedPage.text:
Free wifi hotspots can be dangerous!

 ‘Man in the middle’ can capture all your activity and/or change your destination

  • Use only secure access points
  • Use Virtual Private Networking (VPN) - Windscribe, Touch VPN are free
